bestBHT.bht: When the Holy Spirit enters the heart, it brings about the revelation of God as a Father to the soul, instilling a deep sense of the believer's relationship with God. This profound experience results in the Father and the Son making their permanent, eternal dwelling within the heart of the one who loves and obeys Jesus. Through the constant love and obedience of the believer, the heart of the believer becomes a sacred temple, a glorious and uplifting reality where the Holy Spirit abides.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Astonishing statement! In the Father's 'coming' He refers to the revelation of Him as a Father to the soul, which does not take place till the Spirit comes into the heart, teaching it to cry, Abba, Father.
The 'abode' means a permanent, eternal stay!
Compare Leviticus 26:11; Leviticus 26:12; Ezekiel 37:26; Ezekiel 37:27; 2 Corinthians 6:16; and contrast 2 Corinthians 6:16.
Albert Barnes: We will come to him with the manifestation of pardon, peace of conscience, and joy in the Holy Spirit.
The condition of a sinner is represented as one who has gone astray from God, and from whom God has withdrawn.
They would take up their residence in the heart as their dwelling-place, as a temple fit for their abode.
Marvin Vincent: My word [λογον μου] . The entire gospel message, as distinguished from its separate parts or commandments.
We will come. Compare John 10:30; Revelation 3:20.
Abode [μονην] . See on ver. 2. Compare 1 John 2:24; 1 John 5:15.
John Calvin: The love of God to us is not placed in the second rank, as if it came after our piety as the cause of that love.
He will feel that the grace of God dwelleth in him, and will every day receive additions to the gifts of God.
We must therefore keep in view the design of Christ, that he and the Father will come, to confirm believers, in uninterrupted confidence in his grace.
Philip Schaff: If any one love me, he will keep my word; and my Father will love him, and we will come unto him, and make our abode with him.
The manifestation referred to must be limited, because it can only be made where there is that communion of love...
The climax: no longer ‘I’ but ‘We,’ a fuller presentation of the truth.
Archibald T. Robertson: if one keep on loving me...That is key to the spiritual manifestation.
If the Holy Spirit 'abides' in you, that heart becomes a temple...a glorious and uplifting reality.
John Gill: By his 'words' are meant not his doctrines, but his ordinances; the same with his commandments, John 14:21, which he has said, ordered, and commanded to be observed.
Hence a proof of a plurality of persons in the Godhead, of a trinity of persons, of there being neither more nor fewer than three; since neither more nor less can be collected from the context.

And the constancy and perpetuity of their residence in them, not as a wayfaring man, but always, though this may not be always discerned by believers; and is a wonderful instance of the grace and condescension of God to dwell on earth with sinful men.
John Wesley: Because ye love and obey me, and they do not, therefore I will reveal myself to you, and not to them.
The more any man loves and obeys, the more God will love him.
Which implies such a large manifestation of the Divine presence and love, that the former in justification is as nothing in comparison of it.

bhtAttempts.bht: When Jesus says, If anyone loves me, he will keep my word, and my Father will love him, and we will come to him and make our home with him, it is truly astonishing. This refers to the revelation of God as a Father to the soul, which happens when the Holy Spirit enters the heart. They come to make their permanent, eternal dwelling in a heart that loves and obeys Jesus and keeps His word. By abiding in us, our hearts become temples, where the glorious and uplifting reality of the Holy Spirit's presence is manifest. The love and obedience of the believer are the key to this spiritual manifestation, and it is a wonderful instance of God's grace and condescension to dwell on earth with sinful men.

They come to make their permanent, eternal dwelling in a heart that loves and obeys Jesus. Jesus' statement in John 14:23 is astonishing. It refers to the revelation of God as a Father to the soul when the Holy Spirit enters the heart, leading it to cry out, Abba, Father. The Father and Son come and make their permanent, eternal dwelling in the heart of the believer who loves and obeys Jesus. This spiritual manifestation is only possible through the constant love and obedience of the believer and reflects the glorious reality of God's presence dwelling within us.

When the Holy Spirit enters the heart, it brings about the revelation of God as a Father to the soul, instilling a deep sense of the believer's relationship with God. This profound experience results in the Father and the Son making their permanent, eternal dwelling within the heart of the one who loves and obeys Jesus. Through the constant love and obedience of the believer, the heart of the believer becomes a sacred temple, a glorious and uplifting reality where the Holy Spirit abides.

When the Holy Spirit comes into the heart, He reveals the Father's love and presence to the believer, making a permanent, eternal dwelling within. This intimate relationship is based on the love and obedience of the believer towards Jesus and His word. The believer's heart becomes a temple, where the Holy Spirit abides, bringing forth a glorious manifestation of God's grace and condescension. This extraordinary reality highlights the immense privilege of God dwelling with sinful humanity, all rooted in the believer's love for and obedience to Jesus.
